game_description: The thrill of climbing comes alive with The Climb 2 - explore a new city setting and exhilarating new maps with breathtaking views. Ascend grand peaks, navigate vast caves, climb skyscrapers, and discover hidden shortcuts as you find your path to the top. Compete with friends and conquer leaderboards in asynchronous multiplayer modes. From exploring mountain environments to scaling urban settings, feel the rush of climbing without ropes, and experience breathtaking vistas as you scale new heights.
Languages: English, French (France), German, Japanese, Korean, Spanish (Argentina), Spanish (Chile), Spanish (Colombia), Spanish (Mexico), Spanish (Peru), Spanish (Puerto Rico), Spanish (Venezuela)

review_4: It bills itself as a free-climb game. So, I was expecting to be able to grab pretty much any edge/ledge/wedge I could, even angled surfaces and such the way real free climbers do. Instead, your path is outlined for you with clearly visible white-marked grips on mountains, or certain bricks sticking out of buildings, etc. If you see an angled surface, you can't grip it. You can't wedge your hands into cracks or crevices. It feels very artificial, and breaks the immersion. Because all I have to do is follow the very clearly marked path I'm railroaded along. Others reviewers say other games do poorly with climbing mechanics. Yet I was playing blade and sorcery nomad, and the tutortial level teaches you climbing. I was able to grasp angled surfaces, wedge my hand into crevices, etc, to climb along any path I wanted without it being prebuilt or outlined for me. So, I feel like The Climb series needs to step up its game / realism. Only other major complaint is you have to finish earlier levels on pro mode to unlock harder levels. I just want to play casual without having to worry about stamina, or chalk all the time. So, I wish they'd just let you start a full casual play through that has everything unlocled. Some of us are not hardcore gamers trying to prove our worth. With all that complaining said, it's still a, fun game. It's a puzzle game, though. Because you're trying to figure out which route to go, where to go, how, to position your hands to reorient yourself, etc. It's fun looking around, and it is immersive. The cliimbs are long. Easy levels are at least 15 mins,if youu start out. And your shoulders will feel it in the morning. I don't work up a, sweat in this the way I do with Gorn. This, is more of a "hold your arms up for a long time" game, that works your arms in a, different way for endurqnce. It's a good game, and I, hope, they come out with another. I just want a bit more of a real free climb experience, not "we paintwd this climbing wall to look like a mountain".
